value: file:start of coast to coast - winter.jpg
Start of Coast to Coast walk

The
(properly "
Coast To Coast Walk") is an 190 mile long-distance walking trail in
which crosses the North of England from St Bees in
on the West coast to
in

on the East coast.

The walk was created in 1972 by Alfred Wainwright, when, in response to the creation of the

, he set about devising the best walk he could imagine in England. It has never been adopted as an official National Trail, though a campaign has begun, but is hugely popular and came second (after the

) in a recent poll among travel writers conducted by Country Walking magazine to find the finest walk in the world.

Along its route the walk passes through three National Parks - The
, the
, and the

. The creator suggested walking from West to East in order to enjoy the best possible views, and to have any prevailing weather at your back rather than in your face.

The original guide book was written in Wainwright's characteristic style of hand-written text and hand-drawn maps, in the same manner as his seminal

value: Pictorial Guides to the Lakeland Fells

The walk typically takes people two weeks to complete. You'll want a copy of the guidebook, maps, and suitable outdoor gear. The walk crosses through the mountains of the Lake District but generally keeps to the passes, apart from the occasional option to cross summits.

Walkers may split the walk in various ways to suit the distance they want to walk in a day, though the availability of accommodation may limit this. The author suggested breaking the walk into twelve days, which makes about 16 miles a day. Some find this a little too much for comfort and choose to have the odd rest day or a couple of short days, or even to take other transport as substitution for a day or two.

value: File:St Bees railway station with sign.jpg
St Bees railway station with sign

To
St Bees has a station on the Cumbrian Coast rail line. From the West Coast Main Line, change at
or

off the west Coast main line, or at Barrow-in-Furness. There are currently (2013) 21 stopping passenger trains a day. The station is on the Main Street in the centre of the village, where there are three pubs within 5 minutes walking. It is a 20 minute walk to the official start of the Coast to Coast walk at the main beach.
Leave the M6 at junction 40 (
) and head west along the A66 to
, then south along the A5086 to Egremont. St Bees is a couple of miles to the west and will be signposted.

The walk starts at the seawall at the main beach St Bees; there is a monument to mark this with an interpretation board. The scenery throughout is beautiful, but also varied, since you pass through a number of different types of landscapes. The start is a coastal path walk, with cliffs, seabirds, and a lighthouse. Soon after heading inland you pass through the Lake District, which has a great variety of landscapes in itself. The northern part of the Yorkshire Dales is limestone country, then the Vale of Mowbray is lower level terrain. The North York Moors are peaty moorlands, and finally you reach the sea once more at Robin Hood's Bay among the highest cliffs in England.
For many days of the walk, there will be no pubs or kiosks during the length of the day's walk; avail yourself of a packed lunch.
The Falling Foss tea garden
has tea and a playground for children.

Your main options are Bed & Breakfast (with occasional Youth Hostel options) or camping (including a Mongolian yurt at one point). Some accommodation guides for the walk have been produced over the years.
An option to lighten the load is a daily baggage transfer service, such as Sherpa Van
, who will take your luggage to the next day's finish point for around Â£6 per bag.
Your main risks are being miserable when it rains, and getting blisters. Having the right walking gear is important.
